The XML document is invalid and will not be parsed correctly.

questions.explanation: The parenthetical statement '(if no namespace checking)' indicates that if you check namespaces then it will be invalid, so the validity is conditional. This also implies that it can be well-formed and valid without checking namespace constraints.

DTDs treat xml namespace declaration as a normal attribute and xml namespace prefixes as parts of element/attribute names.

questions.prompt: Which technology fully supports and utilizes XML namespaces, according to the presentation?
questions.explanation: The presentation states that 'XML Schemas support xml namespaces and use xml namespaces.'

snippets: XML Schemas support xml namespaces and use xml namespaces.

questions.prompt: According to the presentation, what does 'XML Namespaces' allow in documents?

options.text: Only one markup vocabulary to be used.
Multiple markup vocabularies to be used.
No markup vocabularies to be used.
Only standard vocabularies to be used.

questions.explanation: The XML Namespace concept allows multiple markup vocabularies to be used in the same documents. (Page 2)

snippets:
Is a concept that allows multiple markup vocabularies to be
used in the same documents.

questions.prompt: Based on the presentation, what XML construct is used to associate a short name with a namespace for ease of use?
questions.explanation: A namespace prefix is used to attach a prefix to a namespace for convenient use of the namespace. (Page 2)

snippets:
A namespace prefix is used to attach a prefix to a
namespace for convenient use of the namespace.

questions.prompt: According to the presentation, what does the scope of an XML namespace cover?

options.text: Only the element in which it is declared.
The element in which it is declared and all of its attributes.
The element in which it is declared and all of its descendant elements.
The element in which it is declared and all of its descendant elements and its attributes.

shortAnswerAccepted: element and descendant elements and its attributes
questions.explanation: The scope of an xml namespace covers the element in which it is declared and all of its descendant elements and its attributes. (Page 2)

snippets:
The scope of an xml namespace covers the element in
which it is declared and all of its descendant elements and
its attributes.

questions.prompt: Based on the information provided in the presentation regarding DTDs, what happens if you try to define two attributes with the same name but different namespaces?

options.text: It is considered a valid XML document under the DTD, provided no namespace checking is performed.
It is considered invalid and will cause a parsing error.
The DTD will automatically merge the namespaces.
The first declared attribute will take precedence.

questions.explanation: According to the DTD example, it's valid, if no namespace checking is enabled. (Page 9)

snippets:
With the namespace concept, one:a and uno:a are
disallowed because of duplicate attribute names.

However, it is valid under this DTD and
well-formed (if no namespace checking).

questions.prompt: According to the presentation, which technology does *not* support namespaces?
questions.explanation: DTDs (in XML 1.0) do not support namespaces. XML Schemas support xml namespaces and use xml namespaces. (Page 8)

snippets: DTDs (in XML 1.0) do not support namespaces.

questions.prompt: According to the provided XML snippet on page 3, which prefix is used for the namespace 'http://www.ns.net/person'?
questions.explanation: In the snippet `xmlns:ps="http://www.ns.net/person">`, the prefix 'ps' is used for the namespace 'http://www.ns.net/person'. (Page 3)

questions.prompt: According to the presentation, how do DTDs treat XML namespace declarations?

options.text: They cause an error in the DTD.

questions.explanation: DTDs treat xml namespace declaration as a normal attribute. (Page 8)

snippets: xml namespace declaration as a normal attribute

questions.prompt: Based on the examples provided in the presentation, which of the following are true about the scope of XML namespaces?

options.text: A namespace declared on an element only applies to that element's attributes.
A namespace declared on an element applies to that element and its descendants, unless overridden.
An element can only belong to one namespace.
If an inner element declares a new namespace with the same prefix as an outer element, the inner element's namespace overrides the outer one within its scope.

questions.explanation: The scope of an xml namespace covers the element in which it is declared and all of its descendant elements and its attributes. (Page 2). The examples show that inner namespaces override outer ones with the same prefix.

snippets:
The scope of an xml namespace covers the element in
which it is declared and all of its descendant elements and
its attributes.

questions.prompt: According to the presentation, how are XML namespace prefixes treated by DTDs?

options.text: As parts of element or attribute names.

questions.explanation: DTDs treat xml namespace prefixes as parts of element/attribute names. (Page 8)

snippets:
xml namespace prefixes as parts of element/attribute
names.

questions.prompt: In the example given on slide 7, what namespace is the attribute `degree` associated with in the `<lecturer degree="doctoral" p:gender="male">` element?
questions.explanation: According to the presentation, default namespaces do not apply to unprefixed attributes. The 'degree' attribute is unprefixed in this case. (Page 7)

snippets:
Default namespaces do not
apply to unprefixed attributes.

questions.prompt: Based on slide 7, consider the XML snippet `<lecturer degree="doctoral" p:gender="male">`. What namespace is associated with the `p:gender` attribute?
questions.explanation: The attribute `p:gender` has the namespace associated with the `p` prefix, which is declared as `xmlns:p="http://www.ns.net/person"` on slide 7.

questions.prompt: Which of the following is a limitation of DTD?

options.text: DTD is written in XML format.
DTD requires the same parser as XML.
DTD has limited support for data types.
DTD supports only complex data types.

questions.explanation: DTD has a limited support on data types.

snippets:
DTD has a limited support on data types; e.g.,
strings, name tokens.

questions.prompt: Which of the following are alternatives to DTD?
questions.explanation: The alternatives to DTD are XML Schema, RELAX NG, and Schematron.

questions.prompt: In XML Schema, what does `schemaLocation` contain when using namespaces?

options.text: A pair of the schema namespace and the schema location.
Neither schema namespace nor schema location.

questions.explanation: `schemaLocation` contains a pair(s) of the schema namespace and the schema location.

snippets:
schemaLocation contains a pair(s) of the
schema namespace and the schema location.

questions.prompt: What are the two main types of Schema Components?
questions.explanation: The two main types are simpleType and complexType.

questions.prompt: Which statement is true about Global Declarations in XML Schema?

options.text: Can only be used where they are declared.
Are not children of the schema element.

questions.explanation: Global Declarations cannot contain minOccurs and maxOccurs.

questions.prompt: Which statement is true about Local Declarations in XML Schema?

options.text: Can be used where it is declared only.

questions.explanation: Local declarations can be used where they are declared only.

snippets: Can be used where it is declared only.

questions.prompt: Which of the following are valid ways to declare an element?
questions.explanation:
The following are valid ways to declare an element:
<element name="." type="."/>
<element ref="."/>
<element name=".">{TYPE}</element>

questions.prompt: In attribute declarations, which keyword defines if an attribute is optional, required, or prohibited?
questions.explanation: The `use` keyword defines if an attribute is optional, required, or prohibited.

questions.prompt: Which of the following are valid simple types in XML Schema?
questions.explanation: string, integer, and boolean are valid simple types in XML Schema.

questions.prompt: In XML Schema, what is the default type if an element is declared with `type="s:anyType"`?

options.text: The element can contain any data type.
The element must contain only numeric values.
The element must contain only string values.

questions.explanation: anyType elements are elements that may contain anything. It is the default.

snippets:
anyType elements are elements that
may contain anything. It is the default.

questions.prompt: How is the hierarchy of built-in data types organized?
questions.explanation: The hierarchy is organized from general types like `anyType` to more specific types like string, integer, etc.

questions.prompt: Which of the following XML Schema elements is used to create a sequence of elements?
questions.explanation: The <sequence> element is used to create an ordered sequence of elements.

questions.prompt: In complex type declarations, what does the term "compositor" refer to?

options.text: A sequence, choice or all element

questions.explanation: A compositor in complex type declarations can be <all>, <sequence>, or <choice>.

questions.prompt: What does the `mixed="true"` attribute signify in a `complexType` declaration?

options.text: The element can only contain other elements, no text.
The element can contain text and other elements.
The element can only contain attributes.

questions.explanation: Setting mixed="true" indicates that the element can contain both text and other elements.

questions.prompt: What XML Schema feature allows reusing a set of attribute declarations?
questions.explanation: Attribute Groups allow for reusing a set of attribute declarations.

questions.prompt: What are the primary ways for deriving new types in XML Schema?
questions.explanation: Types can be derived through restriction or extension.

questions.prompt: Which of the following statements are true about Complex Type Extension?

options.text: It is derived from a simple type.
The derived type looks like the base type.

questions.explanation: Complex type extension enables deriving new types that look like the base type with appended elements or attributes.

snippets: The derived type looks like the base type that have additional sub-elements appended or additional attributes or both.

questions.prompt: What is one of the primary motivations for using XML Schemas over DTDs?

options.text: XML Schemas are written in XML format.
DTD provides better support for data types.
DTD can be used to write the schema using the xml syntax itself.
XML Schemas require a different parser than the XML documents.

questions.explanation: XML Schemas are advantageous because they are written in XML format, unlike DTDs. From page 2: "DTD is used to validate xml documents but the DTD itself is not written in xml format." and "Use the xml syntax itself to write the schema."

snippets:
DTD is used to validate xml documents but the DTD
itself is not written in xml format.
Use the xml syntax itself to write the schema.

questions.prompt: According to slide 3, which attribute is used in an XML instance document to link to an XML Schema document without using namespaces?
questions.explanation:
The attribute `i:noNamespaceSchemaLocation` is used in an XML instance to specify the location of the schema when no namespaces are used. From page 3: `<root xmlns:i="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
i:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="xml-schema.xsd">`

questions.prompt: Which of the following schema elements can be used to define the content of a schema component, as mentioned on slide 5?
questions.explanation: The slide mentions Types `<simpleType>`, `<complexType>` and Contents `<element>`, `<attribute>`. Therefore, all options are correct.  From page 5: "Types: <simpleType>, <complexType> Contents: <element>, <attribute>"

questions.prompt: If you want to declare that an element can appear multiple times in an XML document, which attribute would you use in its declaration according to slide 7?
questions.explanation: The `minOccurs` and `maxOccurs` attributes control the number of times an element can appear. From page 7: `Occurrence: "0", "1" (default), ..., "unbounded"  <element {NAME} minOccurs="." maxOccurs="."/>`

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of the `fixed` attribute in an attribute declaration as mentioned on slide 8?

options.text: To specify the default value of the attribute.
To indicate that the attribute is required.
To define that the attribute must have a specific, unchangeable value.
To specify the data type of the attribute.

questions.explanation: The `fixed` attribute is used to specify that the attribute must have a specific, unchangeable value. From page 8: `Default  <attribute {NAME} fixed="."/>`

questions.prompt: Which XML Schema component is used to define the structure and constraints for the content of elements that can contain other elements and attributes?
questions.explanation: The `<complexType>` is used to define the structure and constraints for elements that contain other elements and attributes. From page 9: `{ComplexType}  <complexType name="."> {Content} </complexType>`

questions.prompt: According to slide 10, which of the following are built-in primitive data types in XML Schema?
questions.explanation: String, integer and boolean are built-in primitive types. From page 10, the data type heirarchy shows that these are all primitive types, where `anyType` and `anySimpleType` are not primitive.

questions.prompt: According to slide 19, what does the mixed content signify in a complex type declaration?

options.text: It allows only character data within the element.
It allows only elements within the element.
It allows both character data and elements within the element.
It restricts the element from having any content.

questions.explanation: The `mixed="true"` attribute in a `complexType` signifies that the element can contain both character data and other elements. From page 19: `This is a <bold>mixed-content</bold> element.`

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of using `<s:group ref="t:fullname"/>` within a complex type as shown on slide 20?

options.text: To define a new group of elements within the complex type.
To include a predefined group of elements into the complex type.
To create a local element within the complex type.
To rename an existing element within the complex type.

questions.explanation: The `<s:group ref="t:fullname"/>` is used to include a predefined group of elements (in this case, fullname) into the complex type.  From page 20: `Groups and Attribute Groups`

questions.prompt: According to slide 21, what does 'Simple Type Restriction' mean?

options.text: Allows multiple choices of base types in its content
Allows multiple occurrences of its base type
Limit the possibility of the simple content of the base type.
Any member of the derived type is also a member of the base type

questions.explanation: Simple Type Restriction refers to limiting the possibility of the simple content of the base type as described on page 21. "Limit the possibility of the simple content of the base type."

snippets: Limit the possibility of the simple content of the base type.

questions.prompt: According to slide 3, what is the default action in the XML schema if the target namespace is not explicitly defined?

options.text: Links the instance to a default target namespace.
Does not validate the XML instance.

questions.explanation: The slide illustrates linking a schema instance without a namespace when the target namespace is not explicitly defined. This allows schema validation without requiring namespace prefixes on elements and attributes in the XML instance document.

questions.prompt: How do you include a predefined group of attributes (attributeGroup) into a complex type using XML Schema, according to slide 20?

options.text: Using the attributeGroup element without a ref attribute.
Using the attributeGroup element with a ref attribute.
By directly declaring the attributes within the complexType element.
Using the xs:import element to import the attributeGroup.

questions.explanation: You include a predefined group of attributes (attributeGroup) into a complex type using XML Schema with the element `<s:attributeGroup ref="t:personAtt"/>`.

questions.prompt: According to slide 2, what is a key difference between DTD and XML Schema?

options.text: DTD is written in XML format, while XML Schema is not.
XML Schema is written in XML format, while DTD is not.
Both DTD and XML Schema are written in XML format.
Neither DTD nor XML Schema are written in XML format.

shortAnswerAccepted: XML Schema is written in XML format
questions.explanation: Slide 2 states: "DTD is used to validate xml documents but the DTD itself is not written in xml format." and mentions using "the xml syntax itself to write the schema" as an alternative, implying XML Schema uses XML syntax.

snippets: DTD is used to validate xml documents but the DTD itself is not written in xml format.
Use the xml syntax itself to write the schema.

questions.prompt: According to the slides, which of the following are XML Node Kinds?
questions.explanation: The slides list Document, Element, Attribute, Text, Comment, Processing-Instruction, and Namespace Nodes as XML Node Kinds.

questions.prompt: According to the slides, which of the following statements about the XML Tree Structure is correct?

options.text: All 7 Node Kinds are always part of the document schema structure.
The order of a node type is not meaningful.
No Node type may have a namespace.
Is Parent-Of  This node type can be a parent of the following nodes.

questions.explanation: The slides state that the 'Is Parent-Of' node type can be a parent of the following nodes.

snippets: In Schema  This node type is a part of the document schema structure.
Node Order  The order of this node type is meaningful.
Have Namespace  This node type may have a namespace.
Is Parent-Of  This node type can be a parent of the following nodes.

questions.prompt: In XPath, how many forward axes are there?
questions.explanation: There are 7 forward axes: child, descendant, descendant-or-self, following-sibling, following, self, and attribute.

questions.prompt: In XPath, how many reverse axes are there?
questions.explanation: There are 5 reverse axes: parent, ancestor, ancestor-or-self, preceding-sibling, and preceding.

questions.prompt: According to the slides, what is the purpose of the 'Axis' component in an XML Path Expression?

options.text: Specifies the type of node to select.
Defines the tree-relationship between the selected node and the current node.
Provides a unique name for the selected node.
Assigns a value to the selected node.

questions.explanation: The slides mention that each step in an XML Path Expression consists of parts including an 'Axis'. It specifies how to move along the XML document in certain directions.

snippets: 1 Axis:: there are 12 axes + 1 deprecated namespace axis

questions.prompt: According to the slides, what is the 'Node Test' component in an XML Path Expression used for?

options.text: To specify a kind of test.
To specify an attribute of a node.
To assign a value to the node.

questions.explanation: The slides mention that each step in an XML Path Expression consists of parts including a 'Node Test'. There are two types of tests to consider.

snippets: 1 Node Test (there are 2 types of tests)

questions.prompt: According to the slides, which of the following are valid Node Kind Tests in XPath?
questions.explanation: The slides list node(), element(), text(), comment(), processing-instruction(), and attribute() as valid Node Kind Tests.

questions.prompt: According to the slides, what is the abbreviated syntax for '/child::node()'
questions.explanation: The abbreviated syntax is simply '/node()'.

questions.prompt: According to the slides, which of the following are functions that operate on string values in XPath?
questions.explanation: The slides list concat(), string-join(), substring(), and normalize-space() as functions that operate on string values. 'deep-equal' is a function on sequences.

questions.prompt: According to the slides, which of the following is a string matching function?
questions.explanation: The slides list contains(), starts-with(), ends-with(), substring-before(), substring-after(), matches(), replace(), and tokenize() as string matching functions. 'concat()' is listed as being a function that operates on string values, while 'avg()' is a function that operates on sequences.

questions.prompt: According to the slides, which of the following is a function on nodes?
questions.explanation: The slides list name(), local-name(), namespace-uri(), and root() as functions on nodes.

questions.prompt: According to the slides, what does the result of an XPath expression represent?

options.text: A sequence of distinct nodes in the document order.
A sequence of nodes in reverse document order.
A string containing the combined text of all selected nodes.

questions.explanation: The slides state that the result of an XPath expression is 'A sequence of distinct nodes in the document order'

snippets: A sequence of distinct nodes in the document order

questions.prompt: According to the XPath Axes diagram, what is equal to ancestor-or-self?
questions.explanation: According to the XPath Axes diagram ancestor-or-self = self  ancestor.

questions.prompt: What is the correct syntax in XPath for selecting all nodes with the name 'tag' in any namespace?
questions.explanation: The syntax for 'local-name' is *:tag

questions.prompt: According to the slides, what are context functions in XPath?
questions.explanation: Position and last are context function.

questions.prompt: According to the slides, in XQuery, what is the purpose of the 'let' keyword?
questions.explanation: The purpose of the let function is to assign a value

questions.prompt: According to the slides, what is the construct operation for Document Node?
questions.explanation: document node = document { content }

questions.prompt: According to the slides, what is processing construct?
questions.explanation:
Processing node = processing-instruction
{ "target" } { "instruction" }

questions.prompt: According to the slides, what is the construct operation for Element Node?
questions.explanation: element node = element elm { content }

questions.prompt: According to the slides, which of the following is a function on nodes in XPath?
questions.explanation: The slide lists `name(), local-name(), namespace-uri(), root()` as functions on nodes. `concat(), string-join(), substring()` are categorized as functions on string values.
